_prev_prog_3.Description: Tri Boro Fruit Co. has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with California's Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program(in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements). At the Federal level, (Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189 Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials), Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations(CFR) 1910.119). This program been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Tri-Boro Fruit Company has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



Tri-Boro Fruit Company, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Tri-Boro Fruit Company has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name          | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia                 Ammonia                     11,390



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.



Tri-Boro Fruit Company has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public saf

ety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Tri-Boro Fruit Company business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary Tri-Boro Fruit Company employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.



PROCESS DESCRIPTION



Tri-Boro Fruit Co. is a commercial cold storage facility for table grapes, citrus products, cherries, and dried fruit.  The facility has an ammonia system that provides refrigeration capacity to two (2) precool rooms, three (3) cold storage rooms, a staging room, and a hallway. The precool and cold storage rooms utilize bunker mounted evaporators while the staging room and dock area utilize ceiling suspended evaporators.  A computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability. 



The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each flooded zone of refrigeration, where it passes through a solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a low temperature & pressure accumulator vessel. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature & pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulator vessels through a suction return line to our main suction accumulator in the engine room.  From there, it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to a thermosyphon vessel and from the thermosyphon vessel it returns to the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel

is supplied to the oil coolers on each screw compressor. High temperature liquid is evaporated in the oil cooler and a combination of high temperature gas and liquid is returned to the thermosyphon vessel by thermosyphon action.  Liquid separated from the suction return gas in the main suction accumulator drains into the liquid transfer vessel.  Operation of a float switch activated solenoid valve raises the pressure in the liquid transfer vessels to the point the liquid can be drained into the high pressure receiver. 



The ammonia system was rebuilt in 1998.  More recently the following projects have occurred:

? 2013 - California Controlled Atmosphere retrofitted the refrigeration system controls



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a water diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.  In addition, ammonia detectors are located throughout the facility, and will shut down equipment if ammonia is detected.  Lastly, an emergency "dump box" contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.



The ammonia system at this facility consists of pipe, valves, equipment, and vessels which are interconnected.  Therefore, the refrigeration system is treated as a single process.



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



GENERAL 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Tri-Boro Fruit Company has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an ac

cidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Tri-Boro Fruit Company facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Tri-Boro Fruit Company has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



EMERGENCY ACTION and RESPONSE PLAN



Tri-Boro Fruit Company's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 

- California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 ?5192(q)

- Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR ?1910.120(q)



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Tri-Boro Fruit Company has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall

plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Tri-Boro Fruit Company continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Tri-Boro Fruit Company's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Tri-Boro Fruit Company's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Tri-Boro Fruit Company has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Tri-Boro Fruit Company has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of Resource Compliance's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.



For the future, Tri-Boro Fruit Company now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Tri-Boro Fruit Company employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Tri-Boro Fruit Company will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
